title: Smoothness
summary:
In mathematical analysis, the smoothness of a function is a property measured by the number of continuous derivatives it has over some domain.[1] At the very minimum, a function could be considered smooth if it is differentiable everywhere (hence continuous).[2] At the other end, it might also possess derivatives of all orders in its domain, in which case it is said to be infinitely differentiable and referred to as a C-infinity function (or
